channel.title: Overclocking help
channel.description:
So far this is the only place on the internet that seems to be helpful in any way what so ever. How do you overclock a processor? I have and Intel Quad Core Q8300 which runs at 2.5 ghz. I've seen on a lot of websites that people have gotten it to run at 3.0 ghz and higher, they just never gave any explanations at how they accomplished this. I'm not a total noob when it come to computers. I built a couple of gaming rigs for my friends and they are working great, I just have no experience with overclocking. I know what overclocking is, I just don't know how to do it.
Mobo: Intel G43 Express Cooling: Zalman 9500 Processor: Intel Quad Core Q8300

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Jeannotvb:

Newer Intel CPU’s have a baseclock (BCLK), so a multiplier of 21x with a BCLK of 133 MHz gives you roughly 2.8 GHz

Wouldn’t know about that since my CPU was made in the stone age.
I assume that the BCLK doesn’t affect the rest of the system, sice you pointed this out, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Jeannotvb
item.description:
johnyo:

RAM speed = FSB x memory multiplier
OCing CPU = raising FSB (in most cases)

Newer Intel CPU’s have a baseclock (BCLK), so a multiplier of 21x with a BCLK of 133 MHz gives you roughly 2.8 GHz

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Fnoigy:

These days, the GPU, RAM size and speed, and HD speeds are the big limiting factors to computer speed these days.

RAM speed = FSB x memory multiplier
OCing CPU = raising FSB (in most cases)

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
I have a PS2 emulator that benefits alot from overclocking, with my default clock of 1.8Ghz* I can play some of the 2D fighting games but with my uber clock of 2.98ghz I can play GTA liberty/vice Stories, God of War, Devil May Cry, Resident Evil, Metal Gear Solid, Burnout, Gran Turismo etc…

*my current CPU at stock is 2.2ghz (E4500), but my 1.8ghz CPU(E2160) should be overclockable to around 3.2Ghz, I am limited by my mobo so I am using the other CPU for the L2 cache (2mb vs 1mb)

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: DethklokSoldier
item.description:
Wish I’d come here first then. I already purchased it from Amazon, and once its shipped its to late to cancel the order. Oh well. At least it will work better than what I’ve got right now.

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Fnoigy
item.description:
I can’t tell you whether or not it does what you want, but I’d still suggest you hold off for another year, enjoy your 220, since it’s still pretty new. The only reason I have a 250 and not my 8800 was because I thought the 8800 was breaking (turns out it wasn’t > ). I like the feeling you get when you make that HUGE upgrade for relatively cheap, and see all the games that used to chug by all choppy-like suddenly come through smooth and clean.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: DethklokSoldier
item.description:
Oh, one more thing, I’m upgrading to a EVGA GeForce GTX 460 in a couple of days. Think that will take care of my Crysis issue, or will I still have to overclock? The GTX 460 I’m buying says that it is “super clocked”, which I’m assuming means that its overclocked.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Fnoigy
item.description:
You’d better believe it is. I’m looking forward to my next system upgrade in a few years so I may be able to see Crysis at 60fps. I don’t care if there’s better graphics out there!! I was happy to see Quake 4 at 60fps for the first time, and I’ll marvel at Crysis at 60fps when the time comes, too!!

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: DethklokSoldier
item.description:
Fnoigy:

Maybe. Crysis CAN be more demanding in the thinky department, but not usually. Also, what specs say you should be able to run it at max settings? Because I’ve got a GTS 250, and a fairly beefy CPU, and I certainly can’t run it maxed out (and hope to average 30fps or higher). That IS what you mean by “lag” right? Sorry, I’ve just been noticing more and more people using “lag” to mean a drop in performance, rather than some aspect of the game lagging behind everything else.

I’ve read the specs for Crysis and based on the recommended specs I should be able to run Crysis on max settings. That reasoning has worked for me in the past, but I guess Crysis is just a different beast all together.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Imonfire
item.description:
DethklokSoldier:

[…]and run 3 different virus and spyware scans[…]

There’s your problem. Try disabling them 3 when playing a game and you’ll see a major difference.

Because I’ve got a GTS 250, and a fairly beefy CPU, and I certainly can’t run it maxed out (and hope to average 30fps or higher). That IS what you mean by “lag” right? item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: DethklokSoldier
item.description:
I have a Nvidia GTX 220 which so far has run most of my games fine, and I’ve had really good performance while running Fallout 3 on max graphics. I want to run Crysis at the maximum graphics, but it lags out. According to the specs my graphics card should be more than enough to run it at max graphics, but my game lags, so I’m assuming its the processor. I have 8 gigs of RAM, which should also be more than enough. Plenty of hard drive space, I defrag once a week and run 3 different virus and spyware scans every night. It almost has to be the processor that is holding me back, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Fnoigy
item.description:
Most games don’t. These days, the GPU, RAM size and speed, and HD speeds are the big limiting factors to computer speed these days.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Brother_Shrike
item.description:
Fnoigy:

Also, what games really use that much CPU power?

GTAIV. BFBC2 as well, but not as much as GTAIV.

also, source doesn’t really benefit from high end graphics, and performance scales pretty evenly as you upgrade your cpu. (not that source really needs an amazing processor to get decent performance).

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Fnoigy:

Where are you getting these numbers from?

OCing any less makes no sense at all. OCing any more probably requires uprgaded cooling, messing with RAM timings and northbridge voltage and understanding at least something about OCing in general.

Fnoigy:

Hell, I upgraded from a so-so processor to one that’s still pretty close to top-of-the-line today, and I really saw almost no difference in system performance.

Well, in that case case CPU is not your bottleneck. Try OCing your GPU!

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Fnoigy
item.description:
johnyo:

Since raising the FSB by definition overclocks RAM and pretty much everything else, I’d say a 25-40% increase is bound to be noticable. Unless the GPU sucks ass, of course.

Where are you getting these numbers from? Also, what games really use that much CPU power? I mean, I guess there’s games like the Tycoon games and X3, or physics-intensive games when there’s tons going on, but other than that, I don’t think any decent processor is really going to have much trouble with most games. Hell, I upgraded from a so-so processor to one that’s still pretty close to top-of-the-line today, and I really saw almost no difference in system performance.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Fnoigy:
  1. Enjoy the almost totally unnoticeable increase in performance.

Since raising the FSB by definition overclocks RAM and pretty much everything else, I’d say a 25-40% increase is bound to be noticable. Unless the GPU sucks ass, of course.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Brother_Shrike
item.description:
Depends how good your processor is and what you’re doing. If you have a shitty processor and you get it up 700 MHz, you’ll probably notice it in cpu-centric games and stuff like rendering. If you have an awesome processor already and you’re in gpu-centric games, you won’t notice shit.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: Fnoigy
item.description:
1. Enjoy the almost totally unnoticeable increase in performance.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
1. reboot PC
  2. enter the BIOS
  3. look around for a submenu containing “CPU clock”, “Vcore”, “Memory multiplier” and stuff like that.
  4. In there enable custom CPU clock and set it just above the default
  5. save and exit
  6. if PC boots fine, increase the clock some more. If it doesn’t, clear CMOS, repeat step 4 and up the Vcore voltage a bit. Search for maximum recommended OC voltage for yor CPU and keep it under that.
  7. Report progress.

[EDIT] just for the record, I don’t know jack shit about OCing

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: DethklokSoldier
item.description:
Truth is I’m not even sure if my motherboard IS an intel motherboard. CPU-Z says its manufactured by ASUSTeK. What’s really sad is that I know how to build and repair computers, but not how to find out what parts I have in my rig, unless they are parts that I installed myself. This is what I get for buying a computer from Best Buy instead of building one this time around. Its an ASUS CG5270 by the way.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking help
item.dc:creator: vivanto
item.description:
King_Kaddo:

The first step to fail at OCing is to post this question on any forum. There are hundreds of tutorials for newb overclockers on the internet.

So much about the op’s assumption of this forum being helpful, fortunately it still is.

As for the topic, the links already posted should help you in the details, but with that Intel mobo I doubt you have the option to OC at all, it needs to be supported from the BIOS which certain manufacturers do better than others, and intel doesn’t support it at all.

But honestly, you don’t really need it anyway, a quad core 2.5ghz is enough for pretty much everything you could use it for. An extra 500mhz would be barely noticeable, only through specific cpu benchmarks, which people only use to show a difference at overclocking anyways, making it totally pointless.

Read full topic
